Name: Resolution designating December 4 annually as Jay-Z Day in the City of New York and celebrating his legendary status as a masterful MC and lyricist and as an innovative entrepreneur.
Title: Resolution designating December 4 annually as Jay-Z Day in the City of New York and celebrating his legendary status as a masterful MC and lyricist and as an innovative entrepreneur.
BodyName: Committee on Cultural Affairs, Libraries and International Intergroup Relations

History.Description: This Resolution was Introduced by Council
This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Cultural Affairs, Libraries and International Intergroup Relations
History.AgendaNote: Cultural Affairs, Libraries and International Intergroup Relations

History.Description: This Resolution was Filed (End of Session)

Text:
Whereas, Shawn Carter was born on December 4, 1969, in Brooklyn, grew up in the Marcy housing projects in Bedford-Stuyvesant, began penning rhymes at the age of nine, and became one of Hip Hop's most renowned MCs (master of ceremonies) and lyricists, known to his fans around the world by countless nicknames over his storied career, including Jazzy, Jigga, Hova, HOV, and Jay-Z; and
      Whereas, By his teen years, Jay-Z became known for not writing down his brilliantly composed lyrics, but simply memorizing them as he wrote them, or, as he explained in his own memoir Decoded, finding "little corners in my head where I stored rhymes"; and
      Whereas, According to The New York Times, this "love of words would give Jay-Z more number 1 albums than Elvis" or indeed any other solo artist, with a total of 14 so far; and 
      Whereas, Jay-Z first attracted widespread attention in "Show & Prove," the celebrated posse cut from Big Daddy Kane's 1994 album Daddy's Home, which memorably showcased Big Daddy Kane trading verses with Scoob, Sauce Money, Shyheim, Ol' Dirty Bastard, and the relative newcomer Jay-Z; and
      Whereas, Many years later in 2012, Jay-Z honored Big Daddy Kane by choosing him as the sole guest star for Jay-Z's eight-show opening of Brooklyn's Barclays Center; and
      Whereas, Jay-Z launched his business career with the founding of Roc-A-Fella Records and released his debut album, the critically acclaimed Reasonable Doubt, in 1996; and 
      Whereas, "Dead Presidents II" from Reasonable Doubt, named by Rolling Stone as number 2 on the list of Jay-Z's 50 greatest songs, refers poignantly to the shooting of a childhood friend and to his own brushes with gun violence; and 
      Whereas, According to Rolling Stone, "Brooklyn's Finest" from Reasonable Doubt, named by Rolling Stone as number 6 on the list of Jay-Z's 50 greatest songs and featuring the Notorious B.I.G., shows off perhaps Brooklyn's two greatest rappers trading "ever more ridiculous crime boasts," including Jay-Z's line "Peep the style and the way the cops sweat us"; and 
      Whereas, According to Billboard, Jay-Z's top five biggest albums include Vol. 2...Hard Knock Life (1998), which was his first GRAMMY Award win, The Blueprint (2001), and The Black Album (2003); and
      Whereas, According to Rolling Stone, "Hard Knock Life (Ghetto Anthem)" from Vol. 2...Hard Knock Life, named by Rolling Stone as number 9 on the list of Jay-Z's 50 greatest songs, was Jay-Z's first single on the Top 15 pop charts and was based on the famous tune from the Broadway show Annie; and 
      Whereas, Jay-Z wrote in Decoded about "Hard Knock Life" that he "found a mirror between the two stories-that Annie's story was mine, and mine was hers, and the song was the place where our experiences weren't contradictions, just different dimensions of the same reality"; and 
      Whereas, According to Rolling Stone magazine's 500 greatest albums of all time, The Blueprint comes in at number 50 and includes "Takeover," described as "one of rap's most precise and unrelenting diss tracks" in which Jay-Z famously "commits GBH [grievous bodily harm] on Nas and Prodigy from Mobb Deep"; and 
      Whereas, As a result of "Takeover," the Jay-Z and Nas beef became one of rap's hottest, with Jay-Z offering these lines on the song to explain why he had sampled Nas on two earlier songs: "So yeah I sampled your voice, you was usin' it wrong/You made it a hot line, I made it a hot song"; and 
      Whereas, According to Rolling Stone, Jay-Z "elevates clever rhymes and innovations with an unmatched air of calm control and a cavalier confidence" on The Blueprint; and 
      Whereas, Jay-Z's first top 10 hit was "Izzo (H.O.V.A.)" (from The Blueprint), and he now boasts 22 Billboard top 10 Hot 100 songs, with the longest-running number one hit "Empire State of Mind," with Alicia Keys, about which he wrote that he decided to "tell stories of the city's gritty side, to use stories about hustling and getting hustled to add tension to the soaring beauty of the chorus"; and
      Whereas, According to Rolling Stone, "99 Problems" (from The Black Album), named by Rolling Stone as number 4 on the list of Jay-Z's 50 greatest songs and put together with Rick Rubin, had "vintage heavy metal riffery reminiscent of Rubin's Eighties work...but lyrically it was a blistering, modern-day critique, taking aim at those who demonize [Jay-Z] as a black man and rapper"; and 
      Whereas, "Crazy in Love," a 2003 Beyonc� single from her debut album Dangerously in Love, came in at number 16 on Rolling Stone's list of the 500 best songs of all time and featured a "killer verse" by her future husband Jay-Z,; and 
      Whereas, According to Rolling Stone, "4:44," named by Rolling Stone as number 15 on the list of Jay-Z's 50 greatest songs and the title track of his 4:44 album (2017), was described by Jay-Z as "one of the best songs I've ever written" and discusses his marital infidelities with a "vulnerability long lurking but never revealed in such a deliberate fashion"; and
      Whereas, His impressive business career continued after the founding of Roc-A-Fella Records with his presidency of Def Jam Recordings for three years and with his 2008 founding of Roc Nation, which oversees a record label, management agency, a clothing line (Rocawear), a streaming service (Tidal), and philanthropies and which has expanded to include partnerships with a wide variety of corporations, organizations, and institutions; and 
      Whereas, Jay-Z's career is one of remarkable longevity, being one of only two artists to score a top 10 hit in Billboard's Hot 100 in four different decades from the 1990s to the 2020s; and 
      Whereas, Jay-Z has earned 88 GRAMMY Award nominations and boasts 24 wins, including for best rap song, best rap performance, best rap solo performance, best R & B song, best R & B performance, best rap/sung collaboration, best rap duo/group performance, best urban contemporary album, and best music video; and
      Whereas, Jay-Z writes near the end of Decoded, "We were kids without fathers, so we found our fathers on wax and on the streets and in history, and in a way, that was a gift...Our fathers were gone...but we took their old records and used them to build something fresh"; and 
      Whereas, Jay-Z's career was commemorated in 2023 with The Book of HOV exhibit at the Brooklyn Public Library's main branch; and 
      Whereas, Jay-Z and the Hon. Dr. Gloria Carter, his mother, founded the Shawn Carter Foundation 20 years ago to open up educational opportunities through college scholarships and more for young people who otherwise might not have access to them; and 
      Whereas, It is unthinkable to celebrate 50 years of Hip Hop without noting the monumental success of a kid from Bed-Stuy, who changed the face of the industry in New York City and beyond; now, therefore, be it
	Resolved, That the Council of the City of New York designates December 4 annually as Jay-Z Day in the City of New York and celebrates his legendary status as a masterful MC and lyricist and as an innovative entrepreneur.



LS #15195
12/1/2023
RHP
5

\pard\ltrpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1\qj Whereas, Shawn Carter was born on December 4, 1969, in Brooklyn, grew up in the Marcy housing projects in Bedford-Stuyvesant, began penning rhymes at the age of nine, and became one of Hip Hop\rquote s most renowned MCs (master of ceremonies) and lyricists, known to his fans around the world by countless nicknames over his storied career, including Jazzy, Jigga, Hova, HOV, and Jay-Z; and\par
Whereas, By his teen years, Jay-Z became known for not writing down his brilliantly composed lyrics, but simply memorizing them as he wrote them, or, as he explained in his own memoir \i Decoded\i0 , finding \ldblquote little corners in my head where I stored rhymes\rdblquote ; and\par
Whereas, According to \i The New York Times\i0 , this \ldblquote love of words would give Jay-Z more number 1 albums than Elvis\rdblquote  or indeed any other solo artist, with a total of 14 so far; and \par
Whereas, Jay-Z first attracted widespread attention in \ldblquote Show & Prove,\rdblquote  the celebrated posse cut from Big Daddy Kane\rquote s 1994 album \i Daddy\rquote s Home\i0 , which memorably showcased Big Daddy Kane trading verses with Scoob, Sauce Money, Shyheim, Ol\rquote  Dirty Bastard, and the relative newcomer Jay-Z; and\par
Whereas, Many years later in 2012, Jay-Z honored Big Daddy Kane by choosing him as the sole guest star for Jay-Z\rquote s eight-show opening of Brooklyn\rquote s Barclays Center; and\par
Whereas, Jay-Z launched his business career with the founding of Roc-A-Fella Records and released his debut album, the critically acclaimed \i Reasonable Doubt\i0 , in 1996; and \par
Whereas, \ldblquote Dead Presidents II\rdblquote  from \i Reasonable Doubt\i0 , named by \i Rolling Stone\i0  as number 2 on the list of Jay-Z\rquote s 50 greatest songs, refers poignantly to the shooting of a childhood friend and to his own brushes with gun violence; and \par
Whereas, According to \i Rolling Stone\i0 , \ldblquote Brooklyn\rquote s Finest\rdblquote  from \i Reasonable Doubt\i0 , named by \i Rolling Stone\i0  as number 6 on the list of Jay-Z\rquote s 50 greatest songs and featuring the Notorious B.I.G., shows off perhaps Brooklyn\rquote s two greatest rappers trading \ldblquote ever more ridiculous crime boasts,\rdblquote  including Jay-Z\rquote s line \ldblquote Peep the style and the way the cops sweat us\rdblquote ; and \par
Whereas, According to Billboard, Jay-Z\rquote s top five biggest albums include \i Vol. 2\'85Hard Knock Life\i0  (1998), which was his first GRAMMY Award win, \i The Blueprint\i0  (2001), and \i The Black Album\i0  (2003); and\par
Whereas, According to \i Rolling Stone\i0 , \ldblquote Hard Knock Life (Ghetto Anthem)\rdblquote  from \i Vol. 2\'85Hard Knock Life\i0 , named by \i Rolling Stone\i0  as number 9 on the list of Jay-Z\rquote s 50 greatest songs, was Jay-Z\rquote s first single on the Top 15 pop charts and was based on the famous tune from the Broadway show \i Annie\i0 ; and \par
Whereas, Jay-Z wrote in \i Decoded\i0  about \ldblquote Hard Knock Life\rdblquote  that he \ldblquote found a mirror between the two stories-that Annie\rquote s story was mine, and mine was hers, and the song was the place where our experiences weren\rquote t contradictions, just different dimensions of the same reality\rdblquote ; and \par
Whereas, According to \i Rolling Stone\i0  magazine\rquote s 500 greatest albums of all time, \i The Blueprint\i0  comes in at number 50 and includes \ldblquote Takeover,\rdblquote  described as \ldblquote one of rap\rquote s most precise and unrelenting diss tracks\rdblquote  in which Jay-Z famously \ldblquote commits GBH [grievous bodily harm] on Nas and Prodigy from Mobb Deep\rdblquote ; and \par
Whereas, As a result of \ldblquote Takeover,\rdblquote  the Jay-Z and Nas beef became one of rap\rquote s hottest, with Jay-Z offering these lines on the song to explain why he had sampled Nas on two earlier songs: \ldblquote So yeah I sampled your voice, you was usin\rquote  it wrong/You made it a hot line, I made it a hot song\rdblquote ; and \par
Whereas, According to \i Rolling Stone\i0 , Jay-Z \ldblquote elevates clever rhymes and innovations with an unmatched air of calm control and a cavalier confidence\rdblquote  on \i The Blueprint\i0 ; and \par
Whereas, Jay-Z\rquote s first top 10 hit was \ldblquote Izzo (H.O.V.A.)\rdblquote  (from \i The Blueprint\i0 ), and he now boasts 22 Billboard top 10 Hot 100 songs, with the longest-running number one hit \ldblquote Empire State of Mind,\rdblquote  with Alicia Keys, about which he wrote that he decided to \ldblquote tell stories of the city\rquote s gritty side, to use stories about hustling and getting hustled to add tension to the soaring beauty of the chorus\rdblquote ; and\par
Whereas, According to \i Rolling Stone\i0 , \ldblquote 99 Problems\rdblquote  (from \i The Black Album\i0 ), named by \i Rolling Stone\i0  as number 4 on the list of Jay-Z\rquote s 50 greatest songs and put together with Rick Rubin, had \ldblquote vintage heavy metal riffery reminiscent of Rubin\rquote s Eighties work\'85but lyrically it was a blistering, modern-day critique, taking aim at those who demonize [Jay-Z] as a black man and rapper\rdblquote ; and \par
Whereas, \ldblquote Crazy in Love,\rdblquote  a 2003 Beyonc\'e9 single from her debut album \i Dangerously in Love\i0 , came in at number 16 on \i Rolling Stone\i0\rquote s list of the 500 best songs of all time and featured a \ldblquote killer verse\rdblquote  by her future husband Jay-Z,; and \par
Whereas, According to \i Rolling Stone\i0 , \ldblquote 4:44,\rdblquote  named by \i Rolling Stone\i0  as number 15 on the list of Jay-Z\rquote s 50 greatest songs and the title track of his \i 4:44\i0  album (2017), was described by Jay-Z as \ldblquote one of the best songs I\rquote ve ever written\rdblquote  and discusses his marital infidelities with a \ldblquote vulnerability long lurking but never revealed in such a deliberate fashion\rdblquote ; and\par
Whereas, His impressive business career continued after the founding of Roc-A-Fella Records with his presidency of Def Jam Recordings for three years and with his 2008 founding of Roc Nation, which oversees a record label, management agency, a clothing line (Rocawear), a streaming service (Tidal), and philanthropies and which has expanded to include partnerships with a wide variety of corporations, organizations, and institutions; and \par
Whereas, Jay-Z\rquote s career is one of remarkable longevity, being one of only two artists to score a top 10 hit in Billboard\rquote s Hot 100 in four different decades from the 1990s to the 2020s; and \par
Whereas, Jay-Z has earned 88 GRAMMY Award nominations and boasts 24 wins, including for best rap song, best rap performance, best rap solo performance, best R & B song, best R & B performance, best rap/sung collaboration, best rap duo/group performance, best urban contemporary album, and best music video; and\par
Whereas, Jay-Z writes near the end of \i Decoded\i0 , \ldblquote We were kids without fathers, so we found our fathers on wax and on the streets and in history, and in a way, that was a gift\'85Our fathers were gone\'85but we took their old records and used them to build something fresh\rdblquote ; and \par
Whereas, Jay-Z\rquote s career was commemorated in 2023 with \i The Book of HOV\i0  exhibit at the Brooklyn Public Library\rquote s main branch; and \par
Whereas, Jay-Z and the Hon. Dr. Gloria Carter, his mother, founded the Shawn Carter Foundation 20 years ago to open up educational opportunities through college scholarships and more for young people who otherwise might not have access to them; and \par
Whereas, It is unthinkable to celebrate 50 years of Hip Hop without noting the monumental success of a kid from Bed-Stuy, who changed the face of the industry in New York City and beyond; now, therefore, be it\par
\pard\ltrpar\sl480\slmult1\qj\tab Resolved, That the Council of the City of New York designates December 4 annually as Jay-Z Day in the City of New York and celebrates his legendary status as a masterful MC and lyricist and as an innovative entrepreneur.\par
